Does time exist without gravity? Yes, time does exist without gravity, that is, it can be found where space-time is not warped (gravity is when space and time, which are parts of a single object called space-time, are warped together). When you are standing upright, your feet are moving more slowly through time than your head is, due to the gravity of the Earth. If you were approaching a black hole, and I was watching from a distance, I would see you slowing down as you get closer to the event horizon, since time is warped, and when you reach the event horizon, I would see you freeze there forever, utterly motionless. You, on the other hand, would not experience time slowing down as you approach the event horizon. Amazingly, time can warp into a space dimension inside black holes, and can even do so at the beginning of the Big Bang. Now, a universe where a law of gravity does not exist is going to look utterly different than the one we find ourselves in. In fact, it may be that a universe requires a law of gravity.

Gravity’s a fundamental property of space. A universe without gravity would be unrecognizable. There certainly wouldn’t be humans. Would there be time? People think of clocks when they think of time but there’re other kinds of time. The most important kind allows events to happen. So. The OP wants to know if there's time without gravity. Probably not clock time - I think a universe without gravity would be too weird for clocks - but, as long as there are particles that change position (events), there will be (some kind of) time.

Time and other assumed spatial dimensions are just high-level mathematical abstractions — there is no "built-in" background space and time among particles, these particles just appear to wander in a virtually built mostly three-dimensional space at some rate. Assuming that time independently flows in an arbitrary point of space is quite misleading, despite what the mathematics of general relativity seems to tell you — these virtual coordinates are just averaged linearizations among discrete interactions of particles in a discrete kind of "space" (which is timeless and spaceless in the sense we contemplate these terms). When there are particles to combine and interact, there will be derived time and gravity, both as averaged and linearized mathematical concepts. The aforementioned is not a part of mainstream physics, it is in my personal opinion.

If time and space forms spacetime, then reversed, or repulsive gravity forms spacetime from a singularity. At the end, gravity is accelerating everything back to a singularity. Time is probably a property of gravity, hence they can’t exist separately.

Yes, most emphatically. The spacetime that is our Universe, with or without gravity, is described in terms of 3 spatial coordinates and 1 temporal coordinate. For example the Minkowski spacetime, which is free of gravity, is described by the metric , and where we clearly have time. The gravity you experience here on Earth is mostly a consequence of the curvature of time.
